elements.content:
A new family of porous lanthanide-based coordination polymers with tunable luminescent properties based on reversible ion-dependent exchange was reported.

The study of coordination-driven self-assembled polymeric metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) is a very active interdisciplinary research area. Such supramolecular assemblies have intriguing structures as well as potential applications as smart optoelectronic, magnetic, catalytic, and porous materials. To our knowledge, only a handful of lanthanide-based porous MOFs which are able to uptake and release guest species in a reversible manner have been reported. In addition, IR, NMR, XRD, and single-crystal analysis are the main monitoring techniques to characterize reversible solid-state guest-exchange processes. Up to now, however, the luminescence properties have rarely been used to monitor guest-exchange processes. The guest-dependent photoinduced emission spectra not only offer a facile monitoring technique to characterize solid-state guest-exchange processes but also provide a practical approach to access of tunable fluorescent materials.
elements.clean_text:
A new family of porous lanthanide-based coordination polymers with tunable luminescent properties based on reversible ion-dependent exchange was reported. 



The study of coordination-driven self-assembled polymeric metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is a very active interdisciplinary research area. Such supramolecular assemblies have intriguing structures as well as potential applications as smart optoelectronic, magnetic, catalytic, and porous materials. To our knowledge, only a handful of lanthanide-based porous MOFs which are able to uptake and release guest species in a reversible manner have been reported. In addition, IR, NMR, XRD, and single-crystal analysis are the main monitoring techniques to characterize reversible solid-state guest-exchange processes. Up to now, however, the luminescence properties have rarely been used to monitor guest-exchange processes. The guest-dependent photoinduced emission spectra not only offer a facile monitoring technique to characterize solid-state guest-exchange processes but also provide a practical approach to access of tunable fluorescent materials.

elements.content: Motivated by our interest in selective and reversible guest-exchange chemistry based on porous MOFs, we have initiated a synthetic program for the preparation of open MOFs, in which the bent five-membered heteroatom-ring-bridged ligands are chosen as the building blocks. We present here the first family of lanthanide-based MOFs consisting of the nanosized Ln2L4 cagelike units which encapsulate the [Mn(H2O)6]2+ cations. These porous coordination polymers can remain intact upon reversible ion-exchange with different Ln(III) cations, which was characterized by the ion-dependent photoinduced emission spectra and XRD patterns.
elements.clean_text: Motivated by our interest in selective and reversible guest-exchange chemistry based on porous MOFs, we have initiated a synthetic program for the preparation of open MOFs, in which the bent five-membered heteroatom-ring-bridged ligands are chosen as the building blocks. We present here the first family of lanthanide-based MOFs consisting of the nanosized Ln2L4 cagelike units which encapsulate the [Mn(H2O)6]2+ cations. These porous coordination polymers can remain intact upon reversible ion-exchange with different Ln(III) cations, which was characterized by the ion-dependent photoinduced emission spectra and XRD patterns.

elements.content: As shown in Scheme , reactions of the bent 1,2,4-trizole bridging ligand L with Ln2(SO4)3·8H2O in the presence of MnSO4·H2O under hydrothermal conditions (H2O, 180 °C), afforded the compounds {[(LnIII 2L4)Mn(H2O)6]·x(H2O)} n (Ln(III) = La (1), Gd (2), Eu (3), and Tb (4)) as colorless crystals in good yield (Supporting Information). Single-crystal analysis (Supporting Information) revealed that 1−4 feature a similar 1D chain motif. For example, the structure of 2 contains two crystallographically independent Gd(III) atoms, which are both found in eight-coordinated dodecahedral coordination spheres that are composed of eight carboxylate oxygen donors from six L ligands (Figure ). The four of eight carboxylate groups from four L ligands behave as the μ2-bridge to bind two Gd(1) ions together, resulting in a Gd2O16 cluster with a close Gd(1)···Gd(1) contact of ∼4.0 Å. Such coordination mode plays a central role in the formation of 2 with a neutral 1D polymeric framework (Figure ). The Gd−O bond distances range from 2.337(4) to 2.677(4) Å.
elements.clean_text: As shown in Scheme , reactions of the bent 1,2,4-trizole bridging ligand L with Ln2(SO4)3⋅8H2O in the presence of MnSO4⋅H2O under hydrothermal conditions (H2O, 180 °C), afforded the compounds {[(LnIII 2L4)Mn(H2O)6]⋅x(H2O)} n  (Ln(III) = La (1), Gd (2), Eu (3), and Tb (4)) as colorless crystals in good yield (Supporting Information). Single-crystal analysis (Supporting Information) revealed that 1-4 feature a similar 1D chain motif. For example, the structure of 2 contains two crystallographically independent Gd(III) atoms, which are both found in eight-coordinated dodecahedral coordination spheres that are composed of eight carboxylate oxygen donors from six L ligands (Figure ). The four of eight carboxylate groups from four L ligands behave as the μ2-bridge to bind two Gd(1) ions together, resulting in a Gd2O16 cluster with a close Gd(1)⋅⋅⋅Gd(1) contact of ~4.0 Å. Such coordination mode plays a central role in the formation of 2 with a neutral 1D polymeric framework (Figure ). The Gd-O bond distances range from 2.337(4) to 2.677(4) Å.

elements.content: The Synthesis of Ln(III)-Coordination Polymers1−4
(Top-left) The coordination sphere of Gd(III); (top-right) the cage unit encapsulating [Mn(H2O)6]2+ guest; (bottom) the 1D chain in 2.
elements.clean_text: 1  (Top-left) The coordination sphere of Gd(III); (top-right) the cage unit encapsulating [Mn(H2O)6]2+ guest; (bottom) the 1D chain in 2.

elements.content: The most important structural feature of 1−4 is that these neutral 1D polymeric chains consist of the Ln2L4 tetragonal prisms4b enclosing the [Mn(H2O)6]2+ cations (Figure ). As shown in Figure , four bent L ligands bridge two Ln(2) ions to form the tetragonal prismatic cage. The dodecahedral coordination mode of Gd(III) center prevents a symmetric alignment of the L spacers, leading to the tetragonal prism being twisted. This structural arrangement leaves openings of 6.8−7.1 Å in the side of the cage. One distorted octahedral [Mn(H2O)6]2+ cation is trapped inside and is hydrogen-bonded to the framework carboxylate moieties (Figure ). Within the cage, the Gd···Gd distance is ∼11 Å and the distance between the two opposite trizole rings is ∼10 Å.
elements.clean_text: The most important structural feature of 1-4 is that these neutral 1D polymeric chains consist of the Ln2L4 tetragonal prisms4b enclosing the [Mn(H2O)6]2+ cations (Figure ). As shown in Figure , four bent L ligands bridge two Ln(2) ions to form the tetragonal prismatic cage. The dodecahedral coordination mode of Gd(III) center prevents a symmetric alignment of the L spacers, leading to the tetragonal prism being twisted. This structural arrangement leaves openings of 6.8-7.1 Å in the side of the cage. One distorted octahedral [Mn(H2O)6]2+ cation is trapped inside and is hydrogen-bonded to the framework carboxylate moieties (Figure ). Within the cage, the Gd⋅⋅⋅Gd distance is ~11 Å and the distance between the two opposite trizole rings is ~10 Å.

elements.content: In the solid state, the Gd2L4 cage-containing chains extend along the crystallographic c-axis. As indicated in Figure , the tetragonal cagelike units permit the chains to arrange tidily in the crystallographic ab plane, generating the squarelike channels along the chain direction. Uncoordinated water molecules are located inside. When viewed down the crystallographic [110] direction, rectangular channels (crystallographic dimensions, 7.8 × 7.0 Å) are evident in 2 (Figure ). So far, a number of 1D metal-organic polymers have been reported, 1D coordination polymers composed of the nanosized Ln2L4 tetragonal prisms, however, are unprecedented.
elements.clean_text: In the solid state, the Gd2L4 cage-containing chains extend along the crystallographic c-axis. As indicated in Figure , the tetragonal cagelike units permit the chains to arrange tidily in the crystallographic ab plane, generating the squarelike channels along the chain direction. Uncoordinated water molecules are located inside. When viewed down the crystallographic [110] direction, rectangular channels (crystallographic dimensions, 7.8 × 7.0 Å) are evident in 2 (Figure ). So far, a number of 1D metal-organic polymers have been reported, 1D coordination polymers composed of the nanosized Ln2L4 tetragonal prisms, however, are unprecedented.

elements.content: The solid state arrangement in2, viewed parallel (left) and perpendicular (right) to the chains.
elements.clean_text: 2  The solid state arrangement in2, viewed parallel (left) and perpendicular (right) to the chains.

elements.content: Coordination-driven lanthanide complexes have attracted considerable attention as promising sensory materials because of their intense luminescence. The luminescence spectra of 1−4 were measured in the solid state. The fluorescence of 1 (λex = 397 nm) and 2 (λex = 368 nm) exhibit one emission maximum at 459 and 428 nm, respectively. Compared to the ligand emission (510 nm), the blue-shift luminescence of 1 and 2 is believed to be based upon ligand-to-metal-charge-transfer (LMCT). Different from 1 and 2, compounds 3 and 4 provide typical emission band features. For 3, the emission bands arise from the 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 1, 2, 3, 4) transitions of Eu(III). The corresponding emission bands are 578, 589, 611, 698 nm, respectively. Among these transitions, 5D0 → 7F2 is the strongest. For 5, four lines of Tb(III) emission can be detected in the visible spectrum, corresponding to transitions from the 5D4 state:  5D4 → 7F6 (489 nm), 5D4 → 7F5 (542 nm), 5D4 → 7F4 (585 nm), and 5D4 → 7F3 (620 nm). The most prominent line was observed at 542 nm (Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: Coordination-driven lanthanide complexes have attracted considerable attention as promising sensory materials because of their intense luminescence. The luminescence spectra of 1-4 were  measured in the solid state. The fluorescence of 1 (λex = 397 nm) and 2 (λex = 368 nm) exhibit one emission maximum at 459 and 428 nm, respectively. Compared to the ligand emission (510 nm), the blue-shift luminescence of 1 and 2 is believed to be based upon ligand-to-metal-charge-transfer (LMCT). Different from 1 and 2, compounds 3 and 4 provide typical emission band features. For 3, the emission bands arise from the 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 1, 2, 3, 4) transitions of Eu(III). The corresponding emission bands are 578, 589, 611, 698 nm, respectively. Among these transitions, 5D0 → 7F2 is the strongest. For 5, four lines of Tb(III) emission can be detected in the visible spectrum, corresponding to transitions from the 5D4 state: 5D4 → 7F6 (489 nm), 5D4 → 7F5 (542 nm), 5D4 → 7F4 (585 nm), and 5D4 → 7F3 (620 nm). The most prominent line was observed at 542 nm (Supporting Information).

elements.content: The porous frameworks of 1−4 are able to undergo a reversible and controllable cation-exchange. The encapsulated [Mn(H2O)6]2+ species are readily replaced reversibly by the [Ln(H2O)8]3+ cations with preservation of the original crystal structure, which leads to luminescence tunability. For example, the crystals of 2 were stirred in an aqueous solution of Tb(ClO4)3·6H2O (large excess) at room temperature for 7 days, generating a new host−guest complex {[(Gd2L4)Tb(H2O)8ClO4]·0.5(H2O)} n (5). As shown in Figure , both emission bands of 2 and 5 are found in the emission spectrum after 2 days, which indicates that the encapsulated [Mn(HO2)6]2+ in 2 were partially replaced by the [Tb(H2O)8]3+ cations. As time goes on, the typical emission intensities of 5 increased, while the intensity of the fluorescence of 2 decreased. After 7 days, no more changes for the fluorescent intensities have been observed, indicating that the exchange reaction of MnII by TbIII was finished. The XRD pattern of 5 indicates that the solid structure of 2 is maintained upon ion-exchange (Supporting Information). Besides the Ln(ClO4)3, the LnCl3 or Ln(NO3)3 can also be used to perform the ion-exchange reactions, but takes a longer time (Supporting Information). Furthermore, the Tb(III) cation in 5 can be replaced by its analogue. For example, the crystals of 5 were stirred in an aqueous solution of Eu(ClO4)3·6H2O (large excess) at room temperature for 7 days to generate the new complex {[(Gd2L4)Eu(H2O)8ClO4]·0.5(H2O)} n (6), in which the [Eu(H2O)8]3+ species are located. The emission spectra (Figure ) and XRD pattern (Supporting Information) demonstrate this ion-exchange process well. More interesting is that 2 can be regenerated when 6 was treated by a large excess of Mn(ClO4)2·6H2O in water for 7 days, which is well confirmed by the XRD pattern and emission spectrum (Supporting Information). Compounds 1−4 are completely insoluble in water owing to their polymeric natures (Supporting Information), so the possibility of a dissolution−recrystallization mechanism for explaining this reversible guest-exchange is impossible.

For example, the crystals of 2 were stirred in an aqueous solution of Tb(ClO4)3⋅6H2O (large excess) at room temperature for 7 days, generating a new host-guest complex {[(Gd2L4)Tb(H2O)8ClO4]⋅0.5(H2O)} n  (5). As shown in Figure , both emission bands of 2 and 5 are found in the emission spectrum after 2 days, which indicates that the encapsulated [Mn(HO2)6]2+ in 2 were partially replaced by the [Tb(H2O)8]3+ cations. After 7 days, no more changes for the fluorescent intensities have been observed, indicating that the exchange reaction of MnII by TbIII was finished. The XRD pattern of 5 indicates that the solid structure of 2 is maintained upon ion-exchange (Supporting Information). Besides the Ln(ClO4)3, the LnCl3 or Ln(NO3)3 can also be used to perform the ion-exchange reactions, but takes a longer time (Supporting Information). Furthermore, the Tb(III) cation in 5 can be replaced by its analogue. For example, the crystals of 5 were stirred in an aqueous solution of Eu(ClO4)3⋅6H2O (large excess) at room temperature for 7 days to generate the new complex {[(Gd2L4)Eu(H2O)8ClO4]⋅0.5(H2O)} n  (6), in which the [Eu(H2O)8]3+ species are located. The emission spectra (Figure ) and XRD pattern (Supporting Information) demonstrate this ion-exchange process well. More interesting is that 2 can be regenerated when 6 was treated by a large excess of Mn(ClO4)2⋅6H2O in water for 7 days, which is well confirmed by the XRD pattern and emission spectrum (Supporting Information). elements.content: Guest-exchanging process of cation species based on2:  (a−c) the solid-state emission spectra (λex = 368 nm) of 2 stirred in a Tb(ClO4)3 aqueous solution at 0, 2, and 7 days, respectively; (c−e) the solid-state emission spectra (λex = 368 nm) of 5 stirred in a Eu(ClO4)3 aqueous solution at 0, 2, and 7 days, respectively; (e−a) show the solid-state emission spectra (λex = 368 nm) of 6 stirred in a Mn(ClO4)2 aqueous solution at 0, 2, and 7 days, respectively. The emission bands of 2, 5, and 6 are shown in green, orange, and cyan, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 3  Guest-exchanging process of cation species based on2: (a-c) the solid-state emission spectra (λex = 368 nm) of 2 stirred in a Tb(ClO4)3 aqueous solution at 0, 2, and 7 days, respectively; (c-e) the solid-state emission spectra (λex = 368 nm) of 5 stirred in a Eu(ClO4)3 aqueous solution at 0, 2, and 7 days, respectively; (e-a) show the solid-state emission spectra (λex = 368 nm) of 6 stirred in a Mn(ClO4)2 aqueous solution at 0, 2, and 7 days, respectively. The emission bands of 2, 5, and 6 are shown in green, orange, and cyan, respectively.

elements.content: In conclusion, a series of 1D lanthanide-based coordination polymers consisting of Ln2L4 cage units with tunable luminescent properties based on reversible ion-dependent exchange was reported. Most importantly, it provides a promising and convenient approach to access the multifunctional luminescent materials that can provide tunable emissions by controlling the type of guest species. We believe that such a property should lead to new, tunable fluorescent materials and sensors.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, a series of 1D lanthanide-based coordination polymers consisting of Ln2L4 cage units with tunable luminescent properties based on reversible ion-dependent exchange was reported. Most importantly, it provides a promising and convenient approach to access the multifunctional luminescent materials that can provide tunable emissions by controlling the type of guest species. We believe that such a property should lead to new, tunable fluorescent materials and sensors.

elements.content: Crystallographic data and CIF files of 1−4, synthesis, emission spectra, TGA traces of 1−4, and XRD patterns of 5, 6, and 2‘. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text:
Supporting Information Available 

Crystallographic data and CIF files of 1-4, synthesis, emission spectra, TGA traces of 1-4, and XRD patterns of 5, 6, and 2‘. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content: Coordination-driven lanthanide complexes have attracted considerable attention as promising sensory materials because of their intense luminescence. The luminescence spectra of 1−4 were measured in the solid state. The fluorescence of 1 (λex = 397 nm) and 2 (λex = 368 nm) exhibit one emission maximum at 459 and 428 nm, respectively. Compared to the ligand emission (510 nm), the blue-shift luminescence of 1 and 2 is believed to be based upon ligand-to-metal-charge-transfer (LMCT). Different from 1 and 2, compounds 3 and 4 provide typical emission band features. For 3, the emission bands arise from the 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 1, 2, 3, 4) transitions of Eu(III). The corresponding emission bands are 578, 589, 611, 698 nm, respectively. Among these transitions, 5D0 → 7F2 is the strongest. For 5, four lines of Tb(III) emission can be detected in the visible spectrum, corresponding to transitions from the 5D4 state:  5D4 → 7F6 (489 nm), 5D4 → 7F5 (542 nm), 5D4 → 7F4 (585 nm), and 5D4 → 7F3 (620 nm). The most prominent line was observed at 542 nm (Supporting Information).

The corresponding emission bands are 578, 589, 611, 698 nm, respectively. Among these transitions, 5D0 → 7F2 is the strongest. metadata.title:
Tunable Luminescent Lanthanide Coordination Polymers Based on
Reversible Solid-State Ion-Exchange Monitored by Ion-Dependent
Photoinduced Emission Spectra
